definitions.definition: a glass or plastic container, usually round with straight sides and a narrow neck, used especially for storing liquids

examples.text: Put the top back on the bottle.
To open the bottle, you twist and pull out the stopper.
He threw his **message in a bottle** into the North Sea.
She filled the bottle with water.
a crowd of youths throwing bottles and stones
Several bags of broken glass bottles were collected.
He threw his empty bottle in the recycling bin.

definitions.definition: the amount contained in a bottle

examples.text: We drank a whole bottle of wine.
She handed me a bottle of water.
We discussed the problem over a bottle of wine.
We washed the food down with a bottle of cheap red wine.
After his wife died, he really **hit the bottle** *(= started drinking heavily)*.

definitions.definition: a bottle used to give milk to a baby; the milk from such a bottle (used instead of mother’s milk)
courage or confidence, for example to do something that is dangerous or unpleasant

examples.text: It took a lot of bottle to do that.
I didn’t think she’d have the bottle to ask him.

definitions.definition: to do something that has a big effect and after which it is very difficult or impossible to go back to how things were before

examples.text: When guns were invented, the genie was let out of the bottle.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French boteille, from medieval Latin butticula, diminutive of late Latin buttis ‘cask’.
